5/6

DeFi should be the way forward. 

As crypto crashed, DeFi lenders got paid back first, liquidations were cleanly executed, none stopped withdrawals, DEXs kept trading. Protocol risk could be analyzed real time. That includes Terra, the only DeFi blowup this cycle so far.

4/6

I've said before that CeFi = TradFi + tokens but it's actually worse.

At least TradFi insures deposits, has capital requirements and enforces audits. 

In CeFi, you get the same degree of opaqueness with LESS accountability and protection.

What even are we doing??

@wfgIII I agree a president accusing media outlets of being fake news is extremely dangerous. I think both examples (Twitter censorship and the fake news meme) are signs of how respect of both free media and free speech is eroding.

@wfgIII Today it's false info about covid. Tomorrow it may very well be something else. Twitter is in its right to do that, but my personal opinion is that it's disappointing to see that a platform used by 100s of millions can and will censor some users.

@betherum1 I'm not an antivaxer. I'm fully vaccinated and wear a mask everywhere. 

I do believe in free speech and I'm deeply against censorship.
@falling_ideas yes, everyone should be responsible for what we say, as well as very discerning with what we read.
@falling_ideas this is not a packed theatre, this is a website made for yelling out 280 character pieces of our minds.

and yes I understand Twitter is a private company and it can ban whoever it wants from its site. That doesn't mean I can't disagree with it.

also, (paraphrasing) I disapprove of what this woman was saying, but I defend her right to say it.

This is getting out of hand. 

And by "this" I mean censorship. There's no "just a little" free speech. We either have it or we don't.

@Camo87586449 @APompliano I donâ€™t see how BTC is superior to ETH as money. We can agree to disagree. 

And donâ€™t think anyone needs to prove anything. The fact is: ETH is being used as money, and by some metrics (# of txs, value transacted) more than BTC is.

@Camo87586449 @APompliano The reason why I think that ETH is money,but not the best type of money, is the same reason why I think BTC isn't the best type of money: volatility. But it ticks all the other boxes (fungible, durable, recognizable), and it serves as collateral for a stable money (DAI).

People are mad and launching ad hominem attacks I will not respond to, but I stand by what I said
1) Layer 3 isn't as secure as Layer 1
2) there is less infra. for lightning than for Ethereum
3) Bitcoin's functionality is limited by design. Ethereum was made for smart contracts

@CharlieShrem Agree that having a simpler protocol like Bitcoin reduces attack vectors, but that's different from multiple layers. How would multiple layers increase security? You have to wait to go through each layer before transactions are confirmed on layer 1.
@Dieter75 Yes, Bitcoin supports some smart contracts. Not nearly to the extent that Ethereum does.
@CharlieShrem This is not Bitcoin versus Ethereum, it's a Layer 3 Bitcoin protocol versus Ethereum

If I wasn't successful in explaining what a financial journalist does, I'm pretty sure I wasn't able to explain Bitcoin. But maybe he's going down the rabbit hole on his own right now and I helped spread the bug to someone who probably needs it more than anyone in Manhattan :)

"I write about cryptocurrencies and other markets. When something newsworthy happens, or I spot something interesting, I write an article" 
"So, like a philosopher," he said.
"No! Like a journalist! ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸"

That really got him interested and he handed me his phone and told me to write it down. I opened Google, did a search for Bitcoin and handed it back to him with the Wikipedia page open. He skimmed the page and asked, "What do you do again?"

"There's no company or country in charge, it's all based on a global network of computers." "ğŸ¤¯ğŸ¤¯ Can buy a car with it?" I told him maybe but it's mostly used as a store of value bc there's no capital controls or hyperinflation, and to trade it bc it's super volatile.

He fully turned around at a red light. "Bit.. what??"I hit the main points about a decentralized network, no central banks, no banks, etc. "Interesting!! So, you're a promoter for the company??" "There's no company!" "ğŸ¤¨ğŸ§"

I clarified saying I write about money and markets. "Oh!! and what brings you here??" I told him I'm writing a book about cryptocurrencies. "Now you really lost me," he said. He had never heard of the term. "You know, like Bitcoin? ğŸ™‹â€â™€ï¸" I said. The rearview mirror wasn't enough.

As is the case with any Argentine taxi driver, he asked me my life story as soon as I got in. He shot me a puzzled look over the rearview mirror when I told him I'm a financial journalist... "finanzas?" he asked. If that was weird to him, I knew it was about to get even weirder.

When you're living and breathing crypto, or even when you're just living in a big city, it's easy to think everyone has at least heard* of the words crypto or Bitcoin. I'm in TucumÃ¡n, a province in Northern Argentina, and my taxi driver just reminded me that's far from true... https://t.co/IlOIWTJICU
